context: revision rhinoplasty and left conchal cartilage harvest to correct nasal deformity.
revision rhinoplasty and left conchal cartilage harvest to correct nasal deformity.
preoperative diagnosis: nasal deformity, status post rhinoplasty.
revision rhinoplasty and left conchal cartilage harvest to correct nasal deformity.
this patient is an otherwise healthy male who had a previous nasal fracture.
during his healing, perioperatively he did sustain a hockey puck to the nose resulting in a saddle-nose deformity with septal hematoma.
during his healing, perioperatively he did sustain a hockey puck to the nose resulting in a saddle-nose deformity with septal hematoma.
during his healing, perioperatively he did sustain a hockey puck to the nose resulting in a saddle-nose deformity with septal hematoma.
the patient did have approximately 12 ml of lidocaine with epinephrine 1% with 1:100,000 infiltrated into the nasal soft tissues.
cocaine pledgets were placed to assist with hemostasis.
a gore-tex small implant had been selected, previously incised.
the patient did have very broad lower lateral cartilages leading to a bulbous tip.
the patient did have very broad lower lateral cartilages leading to a bulbous tip.
the patient had medial and lateral osteotomies performed with a 2-mm osteotome.
the patient had a series of double-dome sutures placed into the nasal tip.
5-0 dexon was employed for intradomal suturing
5-0 clear prolene was used for interdomal suturing
a 5-0 clear prolene alar spanning suture was employed to narrow the superior tip area.
the cartilage from the concha was shaped into a strut and placed into a precision pocket between the medial footplate of the lower lateral cartilage.
hemostasis was obtained with bipolar electrocauterization.
hemostasis was obtained with bipolar electrocauterization.
bovie electrocauterization was also employed as needed.
antibiotic ointment was applied generously.
a telfa was placed both anterior and posterior to the conchal defect and placed in a sandwich dressing utilizing a 2-0 prolene suture.
a telfa was placed both anterior and posterior to the conchal defect and placed in a sandwich dressing utilizing a 2-0 prolene suture.

the inner nasal area was then examined at the termination of the case and it seemed to be hemostatic as well. the patient had a series of brown steri-strips and aquaplast cast placed over the nasal dorsum.

he was charged to home on antibiotics to prevent infection both from the left ear conchal cartilage harvest and also the gore-tex implant area.
